Question: Twenty-one times of a positive number is less than its square by 100. The value of the positive number is
Solution:
Let the number be x, then
According to the question
x2 - 21x = 100 [put the value in options and satisfied the answer or going through detaild method]
⇒ x2 - 21x - 100 = 0
⇒ x2 - 25x + 4x - 100 = 0
⇒ x (x - 25) + 4 (x - 25) = 0
⇒ (x - 25) (x + 4) = 0
Taking,
⇒ (x - 25) = 0
⇒ x = 25
Short Trick:
With the help of options
Let the number be 25, then
⇒ 252 - 21 × 25 = 100
⇒ 625 - 525 = 100
⇒ 100 = 100 (satisfied)

Question: Two pipes of length 1.5 m and 1.2 m are to be cut into equal pieces without leaving any extra length of pipes. The greatest length of the pipe pieces of the same size which can be cut from these two lengths will be
Solution:
HCF of 1.5 m and 1.2 m is 0.3 m
So, the greatest length of the pipe pieces of the same size which can be cut from these two lengths will be 0.3 m.

Question: A General of an Army wants to create a formation of the square from 36562 army men. After arrangement, he found some army men remained unused. Then the number of such army men remained unused was:
Solution: the number of such army men remained unused was 81.

Question: The smallest number, which should be added to 756896 so as to obtain a multiple of 11, is
Solution: So the smallest number is 3.

Question: A boy found the answer to the question "Subtract the sum of 1/4 and 1/5 from unity and express the answer in decimals" as 0.45. The percentage of error in his answer was
Solution:
Sum of ¼ and 1/5 = ¼ + 1/5 = (5 + 4)/20 = 9/20 = 0.45
According to the question
Correct answer = 1 - 0.45 = 0.55
Wrong answer = 0.45
Error in both answers = 0.55 - 0.45 = 0.10
∴ The percentage of error was = [0.10/0.55] × 100 = (200/11)%

Question: The product of two numbers is 48. If one number equals "The number of wings of a bird plus 2 times the number of fingers on your hand divided by the number of wheels of a Tricycle". Then the other number is
Solution:
Product of two number is = 48
First number is = [2 + 2 × 5]/3 = 12/3 = 4
Let the second number be x, then
⇒ 4x = 48
⇒ x = 48/4
x = 12

Question: Natu and Buchku each have a certain number of oranges. Natu says to Buchku,"If you give me 10 of your oranges, I will have twice the number of oranges left with you". Buchku replies,"If you give me 10 of your oranges, I will have the same number of oranges as left with you". What is the number of oranges with Natu and Buchku, respectively?
Solution:
Short Trick:
With help of options
Let Natu has 70 oranges and Buchku has 50 oranges.
If Natu take 10 oranges from Buchku, then Natu’s oranges become = 70 + 10 = 80
Buchku’s remainig oranges = 50 - 10 = 40 (condition satisfied)
Detailed Method:
Let Natu and Buchku has x and y oranges respectively.
Condition first
x + 10 = 2 (y - 10)
⇒ x - 2y = -30 ----(1)
Condition second
x - 10 = y + 10
⇒ x - y = 20 ----(2)
Subtraction equation (1) from equation (2)
y = 50 and x = 70

Question: A square playground measures 1127.6164 sq.m. If a man walks \(2\frac{9}{{20}}m\) a minute, the time taken by him to walk one round around it is approximately:
Solution:
As we know,
Area of square shape playground = a2
⇒ a2 = 1127.6164
⇒ a = √1127.6164
⇒ a = 33.58 m
Perimeter of playground = 4 × 33.58 = 134.32 m
Speed of man = 49/20 m/min
∴ Time to covered 134.32 m distance = 134.32/(49/20) = 54.82

Question: Three electronic devices make a beep after every 48 sec, 72 sec and 108 sec respectively. They beeped together at 10 a.m. The time when they will next make a beep together at the earliest is
Solution:
LCM of 48, 72 and 108 = 2 × 2 × 2 × 2 × 3 × 3 × 3 = 432 seconds
As we know,
⇒ 1 min = 1/60 sec
⇒ 432 sec = 7 min 12 sec
∴ Required Time = 10 : 07 : 12 hrs

Question: Two baskets together have 640 oranges. If (1/5)<sup>th</sup> of the oranges in the first basket be taken to the second basket, then the oranges becomes equal in both basket. The number of oranges in the first basket is
Solution:
With the help of option
Let the number of oranges in first basket be 400,
Number of oranges in second basket = 640 - 400 = 240
1/5th of 400 = 80
After getting 1/5th of orange of first basket, then remaining oranges = 400 - 80 = 320
Oranges in second basket will be = 240 + 80 = 320 (satisfied)
Details method:
Let the number of oranges in first basket be x,
Number of oranges in second basket = 640 - x
According to the question
x - x/5 = 640 - x + x/5
⇒ 4x/5 = 640 - 4x/5
⇒ 4x/5 + 4x/5 = 640
⇒ 8x/5 = 640
⇒ x = 640 × (5/8)
⇒ x = 400
∴ Number of oranges in first basket = 400.

Question: P can do (1/4)<sup>th</sup> of work in 10 days, Q can do 40% of work in 40 days and R can do (1/3)<sup>rd</sup> of work in 13 days. Who will complete the work first?
Solution:
P can do 1/4th of work in = 10 days
P alone can do the whole work in = 10 × 4 = 40 days
Q can do 40% of work in = 40 days
Q can do 100% of work in = 40/40 × 100 = 100 days
R can do 1/3rd of work in = 13 days
R can do the whole work in = 39 days
As we know R has minimum time to complete among three, so R will complete the work first.

Question: Working 7 hours in a day, 4 men can do a piece of work in 8 days. Working 8 hours in a day, the required number of men to perform the same work in 4 days will be
Solution:
As wer know,
M1 × T1 × D1 = M2 × T2 × D2
⇒ 4 × × 7 × 8 = M2 × 8 × 4
⇒ M2 = 7
∴ The required men are 7.

Question: 35 persons are engaged to complete a work in 60 days. After 32 days it is observed that only (2/5)<sup>th</sup> part of the work has been done. The number of persons to be engaged to complete the remaining work in the said period is
Solution:
Remaining days D2 = 60 - 32 = 28 days
Remaining Work W3 = 1 - 2/5 = 3/5
As per know,
[M1 × D1]/W1 = [M2 × D2]/W2
⇒ [35 × 32]/(2/5) = [x × 28]/(3/5)
⇒ x = (35 × 32 × 3)/(2 × 28)
⇒ x = 60
∴ The number of more worker = 60 - 35 = 25

Question: The time taken by 4 men to complete a job is double the time taken by 5 children to complete the same job. Each man is twice as fast as a woman. How long will 12 men, 10 children and 8 women take to complete a job, given that a child would finish the job in 20 days?
Solution:
Short trick:
Let the efficiency of 1 man, 1 women and 1 child be m, w and c respectively.
2 × 4m = 5 c
⇒ 8 m = 5 c
⇒ m : c = 5 : 8
⇒ w = 5/2 = 2.5
Total work = 8 × 20 = 160
Total work done by 12 men, 8 women, 10 children in 1 days = 12 × 5 + 8 × 2.5 + 10 × 8 = 160
Required days = 160/160 = 1 day
Detailed method:
1 child can finish the job in = 20 days
5 child can finish the job in = 20/5 = 4 days
10 children can finish is the job in = 2 days
4 men can finish the job in = 4 × 2 = 8 days
12 men can finish the job in = 8/3 days
4 women can finish the job in = 8 × 2 = 16 days
8 women can finish the job in = 8 days
12 men, 8 women and 10 children complete the whole work in = 3/8 + 1/8 + 1/2 = (3 + 1 + 4)/8 = 8/8 = 1 days

Question: The labourers A, B, C were given a contract of Rs. 750 for doing a certain piece of work. All the three together can finish the work in 8 days. A and C together can do it in 12 days, while A and B together can do it in \(13\frac{1}{3}\) days. The money will be divided in the ratio.
Solution:
\(\Rightarrow 13\frac{1}{3} = \frac{{40}}{3}\)
As we know, money divided in their efficiency ratio.
From the following figure
A + B + C = 15, A + C = 10 and A + B = 9
Efficiency of B = 15 - 10 = 5
Efficiency of A = 9 - 5 = 4
Efficiency of C = 10 - 4 = 6
∴ The money divided among A, B, and C in the ratio = 4 : 5 : 6

Question: A and B together can complete a piece of work in 12 days. They worked together for 5 days and then A alone finished the rest work in 14 days. A alone can complete the work in _____.
Solution:
Short Trick:
Total work = 12
Efficinecy of A and B = 1
Work done by A and B in 5 days = 5
Remaining work = 12 - 5 = 7
Let the efficiency of A be x, then
14x = 7
x = 7/14 = 1/2
A alone can complete the whole work in = 12/(1/2) = 24 days
Detailed Method:
Let A alone can complete the whole work in x days, then
According to the question
5/12 + 14/x = 1
⇒ 14/x = 1 - 5/12
⇒ 14/x = 7/12
⇒ x = 1/24
∴ A alone can complete the whole work in 24 days.

Question: A shopkeeper offers 15% discount on all plastic toys. He offers a further discount of 4% on the reduced price to those customers who pay cash. What does a customer have to pay (in Rs) in the case for a toy of Rs 200?
Solution:
MP of the toy = Rs. 200
SP of the toy after getting two discount of 15% and 4% = 200 × (85/100) × (96/100) = Rs. 163.20

Question: A photographer allows a discount of 10% on the advertised price of a camera. The price (in Rs) that must be marked on the camera, which cost him Rs 600, to make a profit of 20% would be
Solution:
Cost price of the camera = Rs. 600
SP of the camera, if profit 20% = 600 × (120/100) = 720
∴ MP of the camera, if discount 10% = 720 × (100/90) = Rs. 800

Question: A dinner set is quoted for Rs. 1500. A customer pays Rs. 1173 for it. If the customer got a series of two discounts and the rate of the first discount is 15% then the rate of the second discount was,
Solution:
MP of the dinner set = Rs. 1500
SP of the dinner after getting first discount = 1500 × (85/100) = Rs. 1275
SP of the dinner after getting second discount = Rs. 1173
Second discount = 1275 - 1173 = 102
∴ Second discount percentage = [102/1275] × 100 = 8%

Question: A dishonest dealer defrauds to the extent of x% in buying as well as selling his goods by using faulty weight. What will be the gain percent on his outlay?
Solution:
Given:
A dishonest dealer defrauds to the extent of x% in buying as well as selling his goods by using faulty weight.
Formula Used:
successive change% = (a + b + a × b/100)%
Calculation:
The dishonest dealer defrauds to the extent of x% in buying as well as selling
so his net profit = (x + x + x × x/100)%
⇒ gain percent = (2x + x2/100)%
So, none of these is the answer.

Question: In a college union, there are 48 students. The ratio of the number of boys to the number of girls is 5 : 3. The number of girls to be added in the union, so that the number of boys to girls in 6 : 5 is
Solution:
Total number of students = 48
Number of boys = 5/8 × 48 = 30
Number of girls = 48 - 30 = 18
Let the added girls in the union be x, then
According to the question
30/(18 + x) = 6/5
⇒ 150 = 108 + 6x
⇒ 6x = 150 - 108
⇒ 6x = 42
⇒ x = 42/6
⇒ x = 7
Number of girls be added is 7.

Question: There are three bottles of a mixture of syrup and water of ratios 2 : 3, 3 : 4 and 7 : 5. 10 Litres of first and 21 Litres of second bottles are taken. How much quantity from the third bottle is to be taken so that the final mixture from three bottles will be of ratios 1 : 1.
Solution:
First bottle has 10 litres and ratio of syrup and water is 2 : 3
Amount of syrup in first bottle = 10 × 2/5 = 4 litres
Amount of water in first bottle = 10 - 4 = 6 litres
Amount of syrup in second bottle = 21 × 3/7 = 9 litres
Amount of water in second bottle = 21 - 9 = 12 litres
Let the amount of mixture in 3rd bottle be x litres
Amount of syrup in the third bottle = 7x/12 litres
Amount of water in third bottle = 5x/12 litres
According to the question
4 + 9 + 7x/12 = 6 + 12 + 5x/12
⇒ 7x/12 - 5x/12 = 18 - 13
⇒ x/6 = 5
⇒ x = 30

Question: In a coloured picture of blue and yellow colour, blue and yellow colour is used in the ratio of 4 : 3 respectively. If in the upper half, blue : yellow is 2 : 3, then in the lower half blue : yellow is
Solution:
Short Trick:
Blue colour in lower part = 4/7 - 2/(5 × 2) = 4/7 - 1/5 = 13/35
Yellow colour in lower part = 3/7 - 3/(5 × 2) = 3/7 - 3/10 = 9/70
Ratio of blue to yellow in the lower half = 13/35 : 9/70 = 26 : 9
With following option, Taking option 3.
Ratio of blue to yellow in the lower half = 26 : 9 [26 + 9 = 35]
Ratio of blue to yellow in the upper half = 2 : 3 ----(1)
Multiply by 7 in equation (1) so that quantity will be equal.
Ratio of blue to yellow in the upper half = 14 : 21 [14 + 21 = 35]
Ratio of blue to yellow in whole picture = 26 + 14 : 9 + 21 = 40 : 30 = 4 : 3 (satisfied)
Detailed Solution :
Let the total quantity of blue and yellow colour in the picture be 70 unit
Let the the ratio of blue and yellow in whole picture = 40 : 30
Upper and Lower part = 70/2 = 35 unit
Quantity of blue in upper part = 35 × (2/5) = 14
Quantity of blue in lower part = 40 - 14 = 26
Quantity of yellow in upper part = 35 × (3/5) = 21
Quantity of yellow in lower part = 30 - 21 = 9
Ratio of blue to yellow in the lower half = 26 : 9

Question: A and B start an enterprise together, with A as active partner. A invests Rs. 4000 and Rs. 2000 more after 8 months. B invests Rs. 5000 and withdraws Rs. 2000 after 9 months. Being the active partner, A takes Rs. 100 per month as an allowance, from the profit. What is the share of B if the profit for the year is Rs. 6700?
Solution:
Let 4000, 5000 and 2000 as 4, 5 and 2 resepectively for easy calculation.
Total money invested by A at the end of the year = 4 × 8 + 6 × 4 = 56
Total money invested by B at the end of the year = 5 × 9 + 3 × 3 = 54
Ratio of profit of A to B at the end of the year = 56 : 54 = 28 : 27
Total profit = 6700
Being active partner allowance of A = 12 × 100 = 1200
Remaining profit = 6700 - 1200 = 5500
28 + 27 = 55 unit
⇒ 55 unit = 5500
⇒ 1 unit = 5500/55 = 100
∴ Profit of B = 27 × 100 = 2700

Question: A sum of Rs. 15525 is divided among Sunil, Anil and Jamil such that if Rs. 22, Rs. 35 and Rs. 48 be diminished from their shares respectively, their remaining sums shall be in the ratio 7 : 10 : 13. What would have been the ratio of their sums if Rs. 16, Rs. 77 and Rs. 37 respectively were added to their original shares?
Solution:
Total sum = 15525
Distributed sum = 15525 - 22 - 35 - 48 = 15420
Remaining shares of Sunil, Annil and Jamil = 7 : 10 : 13
⇒ 7 + 10 + 13 = 30 unit
⇒ 30 unit = 15420
⇒ 1 unit = 514
New share of Sunil = 7 × 514 + 22 + 16 = 3636
New share of Anil = 10 × 514 + 35 + 77 = 5252
New share of Jamil = 13 × 514 + 48 + 37 = 6767
∴ New ratio of share of Sunil, Anil and Jamil = 3636 : 5252 : 6767 = 36 : 52 : 67

Question: A's income is Rs 140 more than B's income and C's income is Rs 80 more than D's. If the ratio of A's and C's income is 2 : 3 and the ratio of B's and D's income is 1 : 2, then the incomes of A, B, C and D are respectively
Solution:
With the help of option.
Check which ratio has A’s and C’s income in 2 : 3 and B’s and D’s income in 1 : 2. Only option 3 and option 4 have correct ratio. Now check either option 3 or 4 has A’s income 140 more than B. So correct option is 3.
Detailed method:
Ratio of A’s and C’s income is = 2x : 3x
B’s income = 2x – 140
D’s income = 3x – 80
According to the question
(2x – 140)/(3x – 80) = 1/2
⇒ 4x – 280 = 3x – 80
⇒ 4x – 3x = 280 – 80
⇒ x = 200
Income of A = 2 × 200 = 400
Income of B = 400 – 140 = 260
Income of C = 3 × 200 = 600
Income of D = 600 – 80 = 520

Question: A batsman has a certain average of runs for 12 innings. In the 13th inning he scores 96 runs thereby increasing his average by 5 runs. What will be his average after 13th inning?
Solution:
Short Trick:
Average score of 12 inning = 96 - 13 × 5 = 96 – 65 = 31
Average score of 13 inning = 31 + 5 = 36
Detailed Method:
Let average score of 12 inning be x, then
Sum of the runs of 12 inning = 12x
According to the question
12x + 96 = (x + 5)13
12x + 96 = 13x + 65
13x – 12x = 96 – 65
x = 31
Average score of 12 inning = 31
∴ Average score of 13 inning = 31 + 5 = 36

Question: A team of 8 persons joins in a shooting competition. The best marksman scored 85 points. If he had scored 92 points, the average score for the team would have been 84. The number of points the team scored was
Solution:
Let total score be x, then
(x + 92 – 85)/8 = 84
⇒ x + 7 = 672
⇒ x = 672 – 7
∴ x = 665

Question: A librarian purchased 60 story books for his library. But he found that he could get 4 extra books by spending Rs 336 more and then the overall average price per book would be reduced by Re 1. The previous average price of each book was
Solution:
Let the average price of Book is Rs. x each book.
According to the question
60x + 336 = 64 (x – 1)
⇒ 60x + 336 = 64x – 64
⇒ 64x – 60x = 336 + 64
⇒ 4x = 400
⇒ x = 100
∴ Price of book was Rs. 100.

Question: In an exam, the average marks obtained by John in English, Maths, Hindi and Drawing were 50. His average marks in Maths, Science, Social Studies and Craft were 70. If the average marks in all seven subjects is 58, his score in maths was
Solution:
Average marks obtained by John in English, Maths, Hindi and Drawing = 50
Sum of marks in English, Maths, Hindi and Drawing = 50 × 4 = 200
Average marks in Maths, Science, Social Studies and Craft = 70
Sum of marks in Maths, Science, Social studies and Craft = 70 × 4 = 280
Average marks of English, Maths, Hindi and Drawing, science, Social studies and Craft = 58
Sum of marks of English, Maths, Hindi and Drawing, Science, Social studies and Craft = 58 × 7 = 406
∴ Marks scored in Maths = 406 – 280 – 200 = 74

Question: The average weight of 3 men A, B and C is 84 Kg. Another man D joins the group and the average now becomes 80 Kg. If another man E whose weight is 3 Kg more than that of D, replaces A then the average weight of B, C, D and E becomes 79 Kg. What is the weight of A?
Solution:
Sum of weight of A + B + C = 84 × 3 = 252 kg
Sum of weight of A + B + C + D = 80 × 4 = 320 kg
Weight of D = 320 - 252 = 68 kg
E = D + 3 = 68 + 3 = 71 kg
Sum of weight of B + C + D + E = (79 × 4) kg = 316 kg
Sum of weight of B + C = 316 kg - 71 kg - 68 kg = 177 kg
∴ Weight of A = 320 kg - 177 kg - 68 kg = 75 kg

Solution:

15000 8000
8840

Question: The ratio of cost price and selling price of an article is 20 : 21. Then gain percent on it is
Solution:
Given:
Ratio between CP to SP = 20 ∶ 21
Concept used:
P = S.P – C.P
P% = (P/C.P) × 100
Where,
P → Profit
S.P → Selling price
C.P → Cost price
Calculations:
Ratio of CP to SP = 20 : 21
Let CP = 20 and SP = 21
Profit = 20 – 21 = 1
Profit percentage = 1/20 × 100 = 5%
∴ The required profit% is 5%.

Question: The ratio of cost price and selling price 25 : 26. The percent of profit will be
Solution:
Ratio of CP to SP = 25 : 26
Let CP = 25 and SP = 26
Profit = 25 – 26 = 1
∴ Profit percentage = 1/25 × 100 = 4%

Question: A shopkeeper buys a product of Rs 150 per Kg. 15% of product was damaged. At what price (per Kg) should he sell the remaining so as to earn a profit of 20%?
Solution:
Let Cost of 1000 gm (1 Kg) product = Rs. 150
15% of product was damaged, then quantity of remaining product = 1000 × (85/100) = 850 g
SP of 850 gm product = 150 × (6/5) = 180
SP of 1 gm product = 180/850
∴ SP of 1000 gm (1 kg) = [180/850] × 1000 =\(Rs.\;211\frac{{13}}{{17}}\)

Question: Mr. Kapur purchased two toy cycles for Rs. 750 each. He sold these cycles, gaining 6% on one and losing 4% on the other. The gain or loss percent in the whole transaction is
Solution:
Let cost of each cycles = Rs. 100
SP of first cycles = 100 × (106/100 = Rs. 106
SP of second cycles = 100 × (96/100) = Rs. 96
Total CP of both cycles = 100 + 100 = 200
Total SP of both cycles = 106 + 96 = 202
Total profit = 202 – 200 = 2
Profit Percentage = 2/200 × 100 = 1%

Question: A line of length 1.5 metres was measured as 1.55 metres by mistake. What will be the value of the error percent?
Solution:
A line of length 1.5 metres was measured as 1.55 metres.
Correct length = 1.5
Wrong length = 1.55
Error = 1.55 – 1.5 = 0.05
Error percentage = 0.05/1.5 × 100 = \(3\frac{1}{3}\%\)

Question: A businessman imported Laptops, worth Rs 210000, Mobile phones worth Rs 100000 and Television sets worth Rs 150000. He had to pay 10% duty on laptops, 8% on Phones and 5% on Television sets as a special case. How much total duty (in Rupees) he had to pay on all items as per above details?
Solution:
Worth of Laptops = Rs. 210000
Duty on laptops = 210000 × (10/100) = 21000
Worth of Mobile phones = Rs. 100000
Duty on Mobile phones = 100000 × 8/100 = 8000
Worth of Television sets = Rs. 150000
Duty on Television sets = 150000 × (5/100) = 7500
Total duty on all three items = 21000 + 8000 + 7500 = 36500

Question: A man spend \(7\frac{1}{2}\%\) of his money and after spending 75% of the remaining, he had Rs. 370 left. How much money did he have?
Solution:
Given:
A man spends \(7\frac{1}{2}\%\) of his money.
After spending 75% of the remaining, he had Rs. 370 left.
Calculation:
Let the initial amount of money be Rs. x.
After spending \(7\frac{1}{2}\%\) = 7.5% of x, the remaining amount is:
⇒ Remaining = x - 0.075x = 0.925x
He then spends 75% of the remaining 0.925x, so he spends:
⇒ Spent = 0.75 × 0.925x = 0.69375x
The amount left after this spending is:
⇒ Left = 0.925x - 0.69375x = 0.23125x
According to the problem, this amount left is Rs. 370:
⇒ 0.23125x = 370
⇒ x = 370 / 0.23125
⇒ x = 1600
∴ The man originally had Rs. 1600.

Question: On a certain date, Australia has a success rate of 60% against South Africa in all the ODIs played between the two countries. They lost the next 30 ODIs in a row to South Africa and their success rate comes down to 30%. The total number of ODIs played between the two countries is
Solution:
Calculation:
Let a total of 10x match is played between Australia and South Africa
Australia won = 10x × (60/100) = 6x
South Africa won = 10x - 6x = 4x
According to the question,
If next 30 ODIs Australia lost 30 matches, then Australia’s success percentage reduced to 30%
Total match = 10x + 30
Australia lost all 30 matches so, total matches won by Australia = 6x
So,
6x = (10x + 30) × (30/100)
⇒ 6x = 3x + 9
⇒ 3x = 9
⇒ x = 3
∴ Total match = 10x + 30 =10 × 3 + 30 = 60.
Shortcut Trick

Question: Two donkeys are standing 400 meters apart. First donkey can run at a speed of 3 m/sec and the second can run at 2 m/sec. If two donkeys run towards each other after how much time (in sec) will they bump into each other?
Solution:
Given:
Distance between the two donkeys = 400 meters
Speed of the first donkey = 3 m/sec
Speed of the second donkey = 2 m/sec
Formula Used:
Relative speed when two objects move towards each other = Sum of their speeds
Time taken to cover the distance = Distance / Relative speed
Calculation:
Relative speed of the two donkeys = 3 m/sec + 2 m/sec = 5 m/sec
Time taken to cover the distance of 400 meters:
Time = Distance / Relative speed
Time = 400 meters / 5 m/sec
Time = 80 seconds
The donkeys will bump into each other after 80 seconds.

Question: Rubi goes to a multiplex at the speed of 3 km/hr to see a movie and reaches 5 minutes late. If she travels at the speed of 4 Km/hr she reaches 5 minutes early. Then the distance of the multiplex from her starting point is
Solution:
Short Trick:
Distance between stating point and multiplex = [(3 × 4)/(4 – 3)] × (5 + 5)/60 = 12 × (10/60) = 2 km
Detailed Method:
Let distance between starting point and multiplex be x
As we know
Time = Distance/Speed
According to the question
x/3 – x/4 = (5 + 5)/60
⇒ x/3 – x/4 = 10/60
⇒ x/12 = 1/6
∴ x = 2 km

Question: A man travels some distance at a speed of 12 km/hr and returns at a speed of 9 km/hr. If the total time taken by him is 2 hrs 20 min, the distance is
Solution:
The distance is = [(9 × 12)/(12 + 9)] × 7/3 = 12 km
Detailed Method:
2 hr 20 min = 2 + 1/3 = 7/3
Let the total distance be x km.
According to the question
x/12 + x/9 = 7/3
⇒ (4x + 3x)36 = 7/3
⇒ 7x/36 = 7/3
⇒ x = 7/3 × (36/7)
∴ x = 12

Question: A and B are 15 kms apart and when travelling towards each other meet after half an hour whereas they meet two and a half hours later if they travel in the same direction. The faster of the two travels at the speed of
Solution:
Let Speed of a A be A km/hr and speed of B be B km/hr
Relative speed, when opposite sides = A + B
Relative speed, when same sides = A – B
According to the question
A + B = 15/(1/2)
A + B = 30 --- (1)
A – B = 15/(5/2)
A – B = 6 --- (2)
From equation (1) and equation (2)
A = 18 and B = 12
∴ Speed of faster = 18 km/hr

Question: The sum for 2 years gives a compound interest of Rs 3225 at 15% rate. Then sum is
In 3 years Rs 3000 amounts to Rs 3993 at x% compound interest, compounded annually. The value of x is
Solution:
Given:
A = Rs. 3993, P = 3000, r = x% and time = 3 years
Calculations:
A = P (1 + r/100)t
⇒ 3993 = 3000 (1 + x/100)3
⇒ (1 + x/100)3 = 3993/3000
⇒ (1 + x/100) = ∛3993/3000 = ∛1331/1000
⇒ 1 + x/100 = 11/10
⇒ x/100 = 11/10 – 1
⇒ x/100 = 1/10
⇒ x = 10
∴ The value of x is 10
Shortcut Trick
Ratio of A to P
⇒ ∛3339 : ∛3000
⇒ 11 : 10
CI = 11 – 10 = 1
∴ Rate percentage = 1/10 × 100 = 10%

Question: A man borrowed some money and agreed to pay-off by paying Rs 3150 at the end of the 1st year and Rs 4410 at the end of the 2nd year. If the rate of compound interest is 5% per annum, then the sum is
Solution:
A = Rs. 4410, r = 5% and time = 2 years
As we know,
A = P (1 + r/100)t
⇒ 4410 = P (1 + 5/100)2
⇒ 4410 = P × 21/20 × 21/20
⇒ P = 4410 × 20/21 × 20/21
⇒ P = 4000
Again,
A = Rs. 3150, r = 5% and time = 1 years
As we know,
A = P (1 + r/100)1
⇒ 3150 = P (1 + 5/100)2
⇒ 3150 = P × 21/20
⇒ P = 3150 × 20/21
⇒ P = 3000
∴ Total sum = 4000 + 3000 = 7000
Shortcut Trick
If rate 5%, then
Ratio of A to P after 2 years = 202 : 212 = 400 : 441
441 unit = 4410
1 unit = 4410/441 = 10
Hence, 400 unit = 400 × 10 = 4000
Again
Ratio of A to P after 1 year = 20 : 21
21 unit = 3150
1 unit = 150
Hence, 20 unit = 150 × 20 = 3000
∴ Total sum = 4000 + 3000 = 7000

Question: Rs 260200 is divided between Ram and Shyam so that the amount that Ram receives in 3 years is the same as that Shyam receives in 6 years. If the interest is compounded annually at the rate of 4% per annum then Ram's share (approx) is
Solution:
R = 4%
Let the share of Ram be Rs. x and share of shyam be Rs. y, then
As we know,
A = P (1 + r/100)t
According to the question
x (1 + 4/100)3 = y (1 + 4/100)6
⇒ x/y = [(1 + 4/100)6]/[(1 + 4/100)3]
⇒ x/y = (26/25)3
Ratio of x : y = 17576a : 15625a
15625a + 17576a = 33201a
⇒ 33201a = 260200
⇒ a = 260200/33201
Ram’s share = 260200/33201 × 17576 = 137745.104

Question: The radii of two cylinders are in the ratio 2 : 3 and their heights are in the ratio 5 : 3. The ratio of their volumes is
Solution:
As we know,
Volume of a cylinder = πr2h
Ratio of radii of two cylinder R1 : R2 = 2 : 3
Ratio of height of two cylinder H1 : H2 = 5 : 3
∴ Ratio of volume of two cylinder V1 : V2 = π × (R1)2 × H1 : π × (R2)2 × H2 = 22 × 5 : 32 × 3 = 20 : 27
Short Trick :
∴ Ratio volume of two cylinder = 22 × 5 : 32 × 3 = 20 : 27

Question: Three cubes of iron whose edges are 6 cm, 8 cm and 10 cm respectively are melted and formed into a single cube. The edge of the new cube formed is
Solution:
As we know,
Volume of cube = a3
Three cubes of iron whose edges are 6 cm, 8 cm and 10 cm.
Let the edge of bigger cube be A
Volume of cube of bigger cube = Sum of volume of all three cubes
A3 = 63 + 83 + 103 = 216 + 512 + 1000 = 1728
⇒ A = ∛1728
⇒ A = 12
∴ Edge of bigger cube = 12 cm

Question: The radii of two concentric circles are 68 cm and 22 cm. The area of the closed figure bounded by the boundaries of the circles is
Solution:
The radii of two concentric circles are R1 = 68 cm and R2 = 22 cm.
Area of the closed figure bounded by the boundaries of the circles is = π [(R1)2 – (R2)2] = π ⇒ ⇒ (682 – 222) = π × 90 × 46 = 4140π

Question: The radius of a sphere is 6 cm. It is melted and drawn into a wire of radius 0.2 cm. The length of the wire is
Solution:
Radius of sphere R = 6 cm
Radius of wire r = 0.2 cm and Let the length of wire be h cm
Volume of wire = volume of sphere
As we know,
Volume of cylinder = πr2h
Volume of sphere = (4/3) πr3
⇒ πr2 h = (4/3) π R3
⇒ 0.2 × 0.2 × h = (4/3) × 6 × 6 × 6
⇒ h = 72 m

Question: The radius of a wire is decreased to one – third. If volume remains the same, length will increase by
Solution:
Formula used:
Volume of cylinder = π(radius)2 × height
Calculation:
Volume of cylinder = πr2h
New radius of cylinder R = r/3
Let the new length of the cylinder be l unit, then
According to the question, volume remains the same
⇒ πr2l1 = π × (r/3)2 × l2
⇒ l1 = l2/9
⇒ l2 = 9l1
If volume remains the same, the length will increase by 9 times.

Question: In a trapezium ABCD, AB and CD are parallel sides and ∠ ADC = 90°. If AB = 15 cm, CD = 40 cm and diagonal AC = 41 cm. Then the area of the trapezium ABCD is
Solution:
Given,

AB = 15 cm, AC = 41 cm, CD = 40 cm
In right angled ΔADC
AC2 = AD2 + CD2
⇒ 412 = AD2 + 402
⇒ AD2 = 1681 – 1600
⇒ AD = √81
⇒ AD = 9 cm
As we know
Area of trapezium = (1/2) × (sum of parallel sides) × distance between parallel sides
∴ Area of trapezium = (1/2) × (15 + 40) × 9 = (1/2) × 55 × 9 = 247.5 cm2

Question: The area of a rhombus having one side 10 cm and one diagonal 12 cm is
Solution:
Given, a = 10 cm, d1 = 12 cm and d2 = ?
As we know,
4 a2 = (d1)2 + (d2)2
⇒ 4 × 102 = 122 + (d2)2
⇒ 4 × 100 = 144 + (d2)2
⇒ (d2)2 = 400 – 144 = 256
⇒ d2 = √256
⇒ d2 = 16
As we know,
∴ Area of rhombus = (1/2) × (d1) × (d2) = (1/2) × 12 × 16 = 96 cm2

Question: The cost of levelling a circular field at 50 Paise per square metre is Rs. 7700. The cost (in Rs) of putting up a fence all round it at Rs. 1.20 per meter is (Use π = 22/7)
Solution:
Cost of levelling a circular field in 50 piase.(Rs. 1/2) = 1 square meter
Cost of levelling a circular field in Rs. 7700 = 2 × 7700 = 15400 m2
Total area of circular field = 15400 m2
Area of circular field = πr2
(22/7) × r2 = 15400
⇒ r2 = 15400 × (7/22)
⇒ r2 = 7 × 7 × 10 × 10
⇒ r = 7 × 10 = 70
Circumference of circular field = 2 πr = 2 × (22/7) × 70 = 440 m
Cost of fencing 1 m = Rs. 1.20
∴ Cost of fencing 440 m = 440 × 1.20 = Rs. 528

Question: From the four corners of a rectangular sheet of dimensions 25 cm × 20 cm, square of side 2 cm is cut off from four corners and a box is made. The volume of the box is
Solution:
Dimensions of rectangular sheet = 25 cm × 20 cm. If square of side 2 cm is cut off from corners.

Height of box = 2 cm
Length of box = 25 – 4 = 21 cm
Breadth of box = 20 – 4 = 16 cm
∴ Volume of box = l × b × h = 21 × 16 × 2 = 672 cm3

Question: The height and the total surface area of a right circular cylinder are 4 cm and 8π sq.cm. respectively. The radius of the base of cylinder is
Solution:
Given:
Height of the cylinder h = 4 cm
Total surface area of cylinder = 8π sq.cm.
Formula used:
Total surface area of cylinder = 2 πr (r + h)
Calculation:
Total surface area of cylinder = 2 πr (r + h)
2 πr (r + h) = 8 π
⇒ r (r + 4) = 4
⇒ r2 + 4r – 4 = 0
Comparing on ax2 + bx + c = 0
As we know,
⇒ x = [ – b – √(b2 – 4ac)]/2a
⇒ x = [ – 4 + √(16 + 16)]/2
⇒ x = ( – 4 + 4√2)/2
⇒ x = 2√2 – 2
∴ Radius of cylinder = (2√2 – 2) cm

Question: The radius of a cylindrical milk container is half its height and total surface area of the inner part is 616 sq.cm. The amount of milk that the container can hold, approximately, is [Use : √5 = 2.23 and π = 22/7]
Solution:
Formula used:
Total surface area of open cylindrical tank = 2 πrh + πr2
Calculation:
Radius of the cylindrical milk container r = h/2
2 πrh + πr2 = 616
⇒ π (2 × h/2 × h + h2/4) = 616
⇒ (22/7) [h2 + h2/4] = 616
⇒ 5h2/4 = 616 × (7/22)
⇒ h2 = [28 × 7 × 4]/5
⇒ h = 28/√5
Volume of container = πr2h = π × (h2/2) × h = πh3/4
⇒ (22/7) × (28 × 28 × 28)/(5 √5 × 4)
⇒ (22 × 28 × 28 × √5)/25
⇒ (22 × 28 × 28 × 2.23)/25 × 103 litres
⇒ 1.53 litres

Question: A solid brass sphere of radius 2.1 dm is converted into a right circular cylindrical rod of length 7cm. The ratio of total surface areas of the rod to the sphere is
Solution:
2.1 dm = 21 cm
Radius of sphere R = 21 cm
Height of cylinder r = 7 cm
Let the radius of the cylinder = r cm
Volume of cylinder = volume of sphere
πr2 h = (4/3) π R3
⇒ r2 × 7 = (4/3) × 21 × 21 × 21
⇒ r2 = 2 × 2 × 21 × 21
⇒ r = 2 × 21 = 42 cm
∴ Ratio of total surface area of rod to sphere = 2πr (r + h) : 4 πR2 = 2 × 42 × (42 + 7) : 4 × 21 × 21 = 7 : 3

Question: The sum of the length and breadth of a rectangle is 6 cm. A square is constructed such that one of its sides is equal to a diagonal of the rectangle. If the ratio of areas of the square and rectangle is 5 : 2, the area of the square in cm<sup>2</sup> is
Solution:
Let the length of the rectangle be x cm and breadth of rectangle = (6 – x)
Side of the square = diagonal of the rectangle = a cm
Area of square = a2 and area of rectangle = x (6 – x)
According to the question
a2 = x2 + (6 – x)2
⇒ a2 = x2 + 36 + x2 – 12x
⇒ a2 = 2x2 – 12x + 36
According to the question
(2x2 – 12x + 36)/(6x – x2) = 5/2
⇒ 4x2 – 24x + 72 = 30x – 5x2
⇒ 9x2 – 54x + 72 = 0
⇒ x2 – 6x + 8 = 0
⇒ x2 – 4x – 2x + 8 = 0
⇒ x (x – 4) – 2 (x – 4) = 0
⇒ (x – 4) (x – 2) = 0
⇒ x = 4 and x = 2
∴ Area of square a2 = x2 + (6 – x)2 = 22 + 42 = 20 cm2

Question: The length of a side of an equilateral triangle is 8 cm. The area of the region lying between the circum – circle and the incircle of the triangle is (use : π = 22/7)
Solution:
Side of the equilateral triangle = 8 cm
Radius of circum – circle R = 8/√3 cm
Radius of in – circle r = 8/2√3 = 4/√3 cm
Area between the circum – circle and in – circle = π (R2 – r2) = π (R + r) (R – r) = (22/7) × (8/√3 + 4/√3) (8/√3 – 4/√3) = (22/7) × 12/√3 × 4/√3 = 352/7 = \(50\frac{2}{7}\) cm2

Question: A solid sphere of radius 3 cm is melted to form a hollow right circular cylindrical tube of length 4 cm and external radius 5 cm. The thickness of the tube is
Solution:
Given,
External radius of cylinder R = 5 cm
Height of cylinder = 4 cm
Radius of the sphere R1 = 3 cm
According to the question
Volume of cylinder = volume of sphere
π (R2 – r2) h = (4/3) π (R1)3
⇒ (52 – r2) × 4 = (4/3) × 3 × 3 × 3
⇒ 25 – r2 = 9
⇒ r2 = 25 – 9 = 16
⇒ r = 4 cm
Thickness of cylinder = 5 – 4 = 1 cm
As we know,
Volume of Hollow cylinder = π (R2 – r2) h
∴ Volume of sphere = (4/3) π r3

Question: If x<sup>2</sup> + 1/x<sup>2</sup> = 98 (x>0), then the value of x<sup>3</sup> + 1/x<sup>3</sup> is
If a + 1/b = 1 and b + 1/c = 1, then the value of c + 1/a is
If x = y + z then x<sup>3</sup>– y<sup>3</sup>– z<sup>3</sup> is:
Solution:
As we know,
If x + y + z = 0, then x3 + y3 + z3 = 3xyz
Similarly,
⇒ x = y + z
⇒ x – y – z = 0
∴ x3 – y3 – z3 = 3x ( – y) ( – z) = 3xyz

Question: If a + b + c + d = 4 then the value of \(\frac{1}{{\left( {1 - a} \right)\left( {1 - b} \right)\left( {1 - c} \right)}}\; + \;\frac{1}{{\left( {1 - b} \right)\left( {1 - c} \right)\left( {1 - d} \right)}}\; + \;\frac{1}{{\left( {1 - c} \right)\left( {1 - d} \right)\left( {1 - a} \right)}}\; + \;\frac{1}{{\left( {1 - d} \right)\left( {1 - a} \right)\left( {1 - b} \right)}}\) is
Solution:
a + b + c + d = 4, then
⇒ \(\frac{1}{{\left( {1 - a} \right)\left( {1 - b} \right)\left( {1 - c} \right)}}\; + \;\frac{1}{{\left( {1 - b} \right)\left( {1 - c} \right)\left( {1 - d} \right)}}\; + \;\frac{1}{{\left( {1 - c} \right)\left( {1 - d} \right)\left( {1 - a} \right)}}\; + \;\frac{1}{{\left( {1 - d} \right)\left( {1 - a} \right)\left( {1 - b} \right)}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{\left( {1 - d} \right)}}{{\left( {1 - a} \right)\left( {1 - b} \right)\left( {1 - c} \right)\left( {1 - d} \right)}}\; + \;\frac{{\left( {1 - a} \right)}}{{\left( {1 - a} \right)\left( {1 - b} \right)\left( {1 - c} \right)\left( {1 - d} \right)}}\; + \;\frac{{\left( {1 - b} \right)}}{{\left( {1 - c} \right)\left( {1 - d} \right)\left( {1 - a} \right)\left( {1 - b} \right)}}\; + \;\frac{{\left( {1 - c} \right)}}{{\left( {1 - d} \right)\left( {1 - a} \right)\left( {1 - b} \right)\left( {1 - c} \right)}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{1 - a\; + \;1 - b\; + \;1 - c\; + \;1 - d}}{{\left( {1 - a} \right)\left( {1 - b} \right)\left( {1 - c} \right)\left( {1 - d} \right)}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{4 - 4}}{{\left( {1 - a} \right)\left( {1 - b} \right)\left( {1 - c} \right)\left( {1 - d} \right)}}\)
⇒ 0

Question: The simplified value of \(\frac{{\sqrt 3 - \sqrt 2 }}{{\sqrt {12} - \sqrt {18} }} - \frac{1}{3}\; \times \;\sqrt {27} - \frac{1}{2}\; \times \;\sqrt[3]{{27}}\) is
Solution:
Given:
We have to find the simplified value of
\(\frac{{\sqrt 3 - \sqrt 2 }}{{\sqrt {12} - \sqrt {18} }} - \frac{1}{3} \times \sqrt {27} - \frac{1}{2} \times \sqrt[3]{{27}}\)
Concept Used:
Concept of rationalisation: When an irrational number came in denominator in a fraction then it becomes difficult in the calculation. To avoid this problem we multiply something with both numerator and denominator so that the denominator part become rational. This process is known as rationalisation.
In general, the process to make an irrational number to a rational number is called rationalisation.
Calculation:
\(\frac{{\sqrt 3 - \sqrt 2 }}{{\sqrt {12} - \sqrt {18} }} - \frac{1}{3} \times \sqrt {27} - \frac{1}{2} \times \sqrt[3]{{27}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{\left( {\sqrt 3 - \sqrt 2 } \right)\left( {\sqrt {12} + \sqrt {18} } \right)}}{{\left( {\sqrt {12} - \sqrt {18} } \right)\left( {\sqrt {12} + \sqrt {18} } \right)}} - \frac{1}{3} \times \sqrt {27} - \frac{1}{2} \times \sqrt[3]{{27}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{\sqrt {36} + \sqrt {54} - \sqrt {24} - \sqrt {36} }}{{12 - 18}} - \frac{1}{3} \times \sqrt {3 \times 3 \times 3} - \frac{1}{2} \times \sqrt[3] {3 \times 3 \times 3}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{3\sqrt 6 - 2\sqrt 6 }}{{ - 6}} - \frac{1}{3} \times 3\sqrt 3 - \frac{1}{2} \times 3\) \(\left[ \because \sqrt{54}=\sqrt{9\times 6}\Rightarrow 3\sqrt{6}~and~\sqrt{24}=\sqrt{4\times 6}=2\sqrt{6} \right]\)
\(\Rightarrow - \frac{{\sqrt 6 }}{6} - \sqrt 3 - \frac{3}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow - \left[ {\frac{1}{{\sqrt 6 }} + \sqrt 3 + \frac{3}{2}} \right]\)
\(\Rightarrow - \left[ {\sqrt 3 + 1 + \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{{\sqrt 6 }}} \right]\)
∴ Option number 4.

Question: If x = 11, the value of x<sup>5</sup>– 12x<sup>4</sup> + 12x<sup>3</sup>– 12x<sup>2</sup> + 12x – 1 is
If \(a = \frac{1}{{a - 5}}\)(a > 0), then the value of a + 1/a is
Solution:
a = 1/(a – 5)
⇒ a2 – 5a = 1
Divide by a
⇒ a – 5 = 1/a
⇒ a – 1/a = 5
As we know
⇒ (a + 1/a)2 – (a – 1/a)2 = 4
⇒ (a + 1/a)2 – 52 = 4
⇒ (a + 1/a)2 = 25 + 4
∴ (a + 1/a) = √29

Question: If a + 1/b = b + 1/c = c + 1/a (where a ≠ b ≠ c), then abc is equal to
Solution:
a + 1/b = b + 1/c
⇒ (a - b) = (b - c)/bc ---- (1)
a + 1/b = c + 1/a
⇒ (a - c) = (b - a)/ba ---- (2)
b + 1/c = c + 1/a
⇒ (b - c) = (c - a)/ac ---- (3)
(1) × (2) × (3), we get
1 = 1/(abc)2
⇒ (abc)2 = 1
⇒ abc = ±1
∴ The value of abc is + 1 & – 1.

Question: If ax + by = 1 and bx + ay \(= \frac{{2ab}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}\) then (x<sup>2</sup> + y<sup>2</sup>)(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>) is equal to
Solution:
Given:
ax + by – 1 = 0, and
(bx + ay - 2ab)/(a2 + b2) = 0
Calculation:
Cross multiplication rule
\(⇒ \frac{x}{{\frac{{ - 2a{b^2}}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}\; + \;a}}\; = \;\frac{y}{{ - b\; + \;\frac{{2{a^2}b}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}}}\; = \;\frac{1}{{{a^2} - {b^2}}}\)
\(⇒ \frac{x}{{\frac{{ - 2a{b^2}\; + \;{a^3}\; + \;a{b^2}}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}}}\; = \;\frac{y}{{\frac{{ - {a^2}b - {b^3}\; + \;2{a^2}b}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}}}\; = \;\frac{1}{{{a^2} - {b^2}}}\)
\(⇒ \frac{x}{{\frac{{{a^3} - a{b^2}}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}}}\; = \;\frac{y}{{\frac{{{a^2}b - {b^3}}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}}}\; = \;\frac{1}{{{a^2} - {b^2}}}\)
\(⇒ \frac{x}{{\frac{{a\left( {{a^2} - {b^2}} \right)}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}}}\; = \;\frac{y}{{\frac{{b({a^2} - {b^2})}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}}}\; = \;\frac{1}{{{a^2} - {b^2}}}\)
\(⇒ \frac{x}{{\frac{{a\left( {{a^2} - {b^2}} \right)}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}}}\; = \;\frac{1}{{{a^2} - {b^2}}}\)
\(⇒ x\; = \;\frac{a}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}\)
Similarly,
\(⇒ \frac{y}{{\frac{{b({a^2} - {b^2})}}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}}}\; = \;\frac{1}{{{a^2} - {b^2}}}\)
\(⇒ y\; = \;\frac{b}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}\)
\(⇒ {x^2}\; + \;{y^2}\; = \;{\left( {\frac{a}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}}} \right)^2}\; + \;{(\frac{b}{{{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}}})^2}\; = \;\frac{{{a^2}}}{{{{\left( {{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}} \right)}^2}}}\; + \;\frac{{{b^2}}}{{{{\left( {{a^2}\; + \;{b^2}} \right)}^2}}}\; = \;\frac{1}{{({a^2}\; + \;{b^2})}}\)
∴ (x2 + y2) (a2 + b2) = 1
Important Points
In a cross multiplication method, we multiply the numerator of one fraction to the denominator of other and denominator of the first term to the numerator of another term.
Alternate Method:
ax + by = 1 -----------(1)
bx + ay = 2ab/(a2+ b2) ------------(2)
On dividing eq (1)/(2) we get,
⇒ (ax + by)/(bx + ay) = (a2 + b2)/2ab
⇒ 2a2xb + 2ab2y = a2bx + b3x + a3y + ab2y
⇒ a2xb + ab2y = b3x + a3y
⇒ a2bx - b3x = a3y - ab2y
⇒ x(a2b - b3) = y(a3 - ab2)
⇒ x/y = (a3 - ab2)/(a2b - b3)
⇒ x/y = a(a2 - b2)/b(a2 - b2)
x/y =a/b -----------(3)
Now putting value of x and y from eq (3) in eq (1) we get,
y = b/(a2 + b2)
x = a/(a2 + b2)
⇒ x2 + y2 = a2/(a2 + b2)2+ b2/(a2 + b2)2
⇒ x2 + y2 = 1/(a2 + b2)
(x2 + y2)(a2 + b2) = 1

Question: If x, y, z are the three factors of a<sup>3</sup>– 7a – 6, then value of x + y + z will be
ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral of which AB is the diameter. Diagonals AC and BD intersect at E. If ∠DBC = 35°, then ∠AED measures
Solution:
As we know,
∠ACB = 90
In ΔBEC
∠ECB + ∠EBC + ∠BEC = 180
⇒ ∠BEC = 180 – 90 – 35 = 55
⇒ ∠BEC = ∠AED = 55 [Vertically opposite angle]

Question: In a triangle ABC, ∠A = 70°, ∠B = 80° and O is the incentre of ΔABC. ∠ACB = 2x° and ∠BOC = y°. The values of x and y, respectively are
Solution:
In ΔABC,
∠A + ∠B + ∠C = 180
⇒ 70 + 80 + ∠C = 180
⇒ ∠C = 180 – 150 = 30
∠ACB = 30
⇒ 2x = 30°
⇒ x = 15°
As we know,
∠OBC = ∠B/2 = 80/2 = 40
∠OCB = ∠C/2 = 30/2 = 15
In ΔBOC
∠OBC + ∠OCB + ∠BOC = 180
⇒ 40 + 15 + ∠BOC = 180
∠BOC = 180° – 55° = 125°
⇒ y = 125°

Question: In a right – angled triangle ΔDEF, if the length of the hypotenuse EF is 12 cm, then the length of the median DX is
Solution:
As we know,
Median of right angled triangle = EF/2 = 12/2 = 6 cm

Question: Two equal circles intersect so that their centres, and the points at which they intersect form a square of side 1 cm. The area (in sq.cm) of the portion that is common to the circles is
Solution:
Square = AOBO’
Side of the square a = 1 cm
Area of the square = 1 cm2
Area of sector AOB = πr2 × 90/360 = π/4
Area of sector AO’B = πr2 × 90/360 = π/4
∴ Area of the portion that is common to the circles = π/4 + π/4 – 1 = π/2 – 1

Question: PQRA is a rectangle, AP = 22 cm, PQ = 8 cm. ΔABC is a triangle whose vertices lie on the sides of PQRA such that BQ = 2 cm and QC = 16 cm, then the length of the line joining the mid points of the sides AB and BC is
Solution:
PQRA is a rectangle, then
QR = AP = 22 cm and AR = PQ = 8 cm, BQ = 2 cm and QC = 16 cm
RC = QR – QC = 22 – 16 = 6 cm
In ΔARC
AC2 = AR2 + RC2
⇒ AC2 = 82 + 62
⇒ AC2 = 64 + 36
⇒ AC = √100 = 10 cm
Let D and E are mid – point of AB and AC, then
BD = DC and BE = EA
As we know,
⇒ DE = AC/2 = 10/2 = 5 cm

Question: ΔABC is an isosceles right – angled triangle having ∠C = 90°. If D is any point on AB, then AD<sup>2</sup> + BD<sup>2</sup> is equal to
Solution:
AC2 + CB2 = AB2
⇒ 2BC2 = (AD + DB)2
2BC2 = AD2 + DB2 + 2AD × BD ------ (1)
In right angled ∆CED
CD2 = CE2 + ED2 ------ (2)
In right angled ∆ CEB
BC2 = CE2 + BE2 ------ (3)
From equation (3) and equation (2)
BC2 – CD2 = BE2 – DE2
⇒ BC2 – CD2 = (BE + DE) (BE – DE)
⇒ BC2 – CD2 = (AE + DE) (BE – DE)
⇒ BC2 – CD2 = AD × BD ------ (4)
From equations (1) and equation (4)
∴ AD2 + DB2 = 2CD2

Question: D and E are points on the sides AB and AC respectively of ΔABC such that DE is parallel to BC and AD : DB = 4 : 5, CD and BE intersect each other at F. Then the ratio of the areas of ΔDEF and ΔCBF
Solution:
In ΔABC and In ΔADE
AD/AB = DE/BC
⇒ DE/BC = 4/9
Area of ΔDEF : Area of ΔBFC = DE2 : BC2 = 42 : 92 = 16 : 81

Question: Diagonals of a trapezium ABCD with AB II CD intersect each other at the point O. If AB = 2CD, then the ratio of the areas of ΔAOB and ΔCOD is
Solution:
AB = 2CD
AB : CD = 2 : 1
In ΔABO and In ΔDOC
∴ Area of ΔAOB : Area of ΔCOD = AB2 : CD2 = 22 : 12 = 4 : 1

Question: If O is the orthocentre of ΔABC and ∠BOC = 100°, the measure of ∠BAC is
Solution:
From the following figure
∠ODA = ∠OEA = 90 and ∠BOC = ∠DOE = 100
In quadrilateral ADOE
∠ADO + ∠DOE + ∠OEA + ∠ DAE = 360
⇒ 90 + 100 + 90 + ∠DAE = 360
⇒ ∠DAE = 360 – 280 = 80
Short Trick:
∠BOC + ∠BAC = 180
⇒ ∠BAC = 180 – 100 = 80

Question: PQ and RS are common tangents to two circles intersecting at A and B. AB, when produced both sides, meet the tangents PQ and RS at X and Y, respectively. If AB = 3 cm, XY = 5 cm, then PQ (in cm) will be
Solution:
Given,
XY = 5 cm and AB = 3 cm
As we know,
⇒ XA = YB
⇒ XY = XA + AB + BY
⇒ 5 = 2XA + 3
⇒ 2XA = 5 – 3 = 2
⇒ XA = 1
XB = XA + AB = 1 + 3 = 4
As we know,
PX2 = XA × XB
⇒ PX2 = 1 × 4
⇒ PX = 2 cm
Similarly,
XQ = 2 cm
⇒ PQ = PX + XQ = 2 + 2 = 4 cm

Question: If secA + tanA = a, then the value of cosA is
Solution:
sec A + tan A = a ----(1)
As we know,
sec2 A – tan2 A = 1
⇒ (sec A – tan A) (sec A + tan A) = 1
⇒ sec A – tan A = 1/a ----(2)
from equation (1) and equation (2)
2 sec A = a + 1/a
⇒ sec A = (a2 + 1)/2a
⇒ cos A = 2a/(a2 + 1)

Question: If sin P + cosec P = 2, then the value of sin<sup>7</sup>P + cosec<sup>7</sup>P is
Solution:
sin P + cosec P = 2
Put P = 90
sin 90 + cosec 90 = 2
⇒ 1 + 1 = 2
⇒ 2 = 2 (satisfied)
sin7 P + cosec7 P
⇒ sin7 90 + cosec7 90
⇒ 1 + 1
⇒ 2

Question: If cosx.cosy + sinx.siny = – 1 then cosx + cosy is
Solution:
cosx.cosy + sinx.siny = – 1
⇒ cos (x – y) = – 1
⇒ cos (x – y) = cos 180
⇒ x – y = 180
Let x = 180 and y = 0, then
cosx + cosy
⇒ cos 180 + cos0
⇒ – 1 + 1
⇒ 0

Question: The value of the expression 2(sin<sup>6</sup>θ + cos<sup>6</sup>θ) – 3(sin<sup>4</sup>θ + cos<sup>4</sup>θ) + 1 is
Solution:
2(sin6θ + cos6θ) – 3(sin4θ + cos4θ) + 1
Put θ = 0, then
⇒ 2(0 + 1) – 3 (0 + 1) + 1
⇒ 2 – 3 + 1
⇒ 0

Question: If \(\cos \theta = \frac{{{x^2} - {y^2}}}{{{x^2}\; + \;{y^2}}}\) then the value of cot θ is equal to [If 0° ≤ θ ≤ 90°]
Solution:
\(\cos \theta {\rm{}} = {\rm{}}\frac{{{x^2} - {y^2}}}{{{x^2}{\rm{\;}} + {\rm{\;}}{y^2}}}\)
Perpendicular = P, Hypotenuse = H and Base = B.
cos θ = B/H = (x2 – y2)/(x2 + y2)
⇒ H = x2 + y2 and B = x2 – y2
As we know,
H2 = P2 + B2
⇒ (x2 + y)2 = P2 + (x2 – y2)2
⇒ P2 = (x2 + y2)2 – (x2 – y2)2
⇒ P2 = 4x2y2
⇒ P = 2xy
⇒ cot A = B/P = (x2 – y2)/2xy
Short Trick:
cos θ = B/H = (x2 – y2)/(x2 + y2)
⇒ cot θ = B/H
As we know, B = (x2 – y2)
Only option 4 has in numerator (x2 – y2)

Question: The distance between two pillars is 120 metres. The height of one pillar is thrice the other. The angles of elevation of their tops from the midpoint of the line connecting their feet are complementary to each other. The height (in metres) of the taller pillar is (Use: √3 = 1.732)
Solution:
From the following figure,
BD = 120 and BC = CD = 120/2 = 60
Let AB = x and DE = 3x
In ΔABC
tan θ = AB/BC
⇒ tan θ = x/60 ----(1)
⇒ tan (90 – θ) = DE/CD
⇒ cot θ = 3x/60 ----(2)
Multiply by (1) and (2)
tan θ cot θ = (x/60) × (3x/60)
⇒ 1 = 3x2/(60 × 60)
⇒ x2 = (60 × 60)/3 = 20 × 20 × 3
⇒ x = 20 √3
Length of taller pillar DE = 3 × 20√3 = 60 × 1.732 = 103.92

Question: If x = cosecθ – sinθ and y = secθ – cosθ, then the relation between x and y is
Solution:
x = cosecθ – sinθ and y = secθ – cosθ
Put θ = 45
⇒ x = cosec 45 – sin 45
⇒ x = √2 – 1/√2
⇒ x = 1/√2
⇒ y = sec 45 – cos 45
⇒ y = √2 – 1/√2
⇒ y = 1/√2
Now, check option one by one.
x2y2 (x2+ y2+ 3) = 1
⇒ (1/√2)2 (1/√2)2 [(1/√2)2 + (1/√2)2 + 3] = 1
⇒ 1/2 × 1/2 [1/2 + ½ + 3] = 1
⇒ 1/4 × 4 = 1
⇒ 1 = 1 (satisfied)

Question: A hydrogen filled balloon ascending at the rate of 18 kmph was drifted by wind. Its angle of elevation at 10<sup>th</sup> and 15<sup>th</sup> minutes were found to be 60° and 45° respectively. The wind speed (in whole numbers) during the last five minutes, approximately, is equal to
Solution:
According to question,
After 10 minutes balloon will be at Point B and after 15 minutes balloon will be at point C.
Now,
BD = Time × Speed
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{10}}{{60}} \times 18 \Rightarrow 3km\)
Also, CE = Time × Speed
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{15}}{{60}} \times 18 \Rightarrow 4.5km\)
CF = CE – BD ⇒ 4.5 – 3 = 1.5 km
Now, In ΔBDA
\(\tan 60^\circ = \frac{{BD}}{{AD}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \sqrt 3 = \frac{3}{{AD}}\)
⇒ AD = √3
In ΔCAE
\(\tan 45^\circ = \frac{{CE}}{{AE}}\)
⇒ AE = 4.5
DE = AE – AD = 4.5 - √3
Also DE = BF
As are know
\(Speed = \frac{{Distance}}{{Time}} = \frac{{BF}}{{5\;minutes}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{4.5 - \sqrt 3 }}{{5/60}} \Rightarrow \frac{{4.5 - 1.732}}{{5 \div 60}} \Rightarrow \frac{{2.768}}{5} \times 60\)
⇒ 33.216 ≈ 33 km/hr

Question: The angle of elevation of an aeroplane as observed from a point 30 m above the transparent water – surface of a lake is 30° and the angle of depression of the image of the aeroplane in the water of the lake is 60°. The height of the aeroplane from the water – surface of the lake is
Solution:
From the following figure,
Height of aeroplane CQ = x cm
AP = BQ = 30 cm
⇒ CB = x + 30
⇒ CB = BD = x + 30
⇒ QD = 30 + x + 30 = x + 60
In ΔPCQ
tan 30 = CQ/PQ
⇒ 1/√3 = x/PQ
⇒ PQ = √3 x ----(1)
In ΔPDQ
tan 60 = QD/PQ
⇒ √3 = (x + 60)/PQ
PQ = (x + 60)/√3 ----(2)
From equation (1) and equation (2)
√3 x = (x + 60)/√3
⇒ 3x = x + 60
⇒ 2x = 60
⇒ x = 30
∴ Height of aeroplane from the surface of lake = CQ + QB = 30 + 30 = 60 m

Question: The angles of depression of two ships from the top of a light house are 60° and 45° towards east. If the ships are 300 m apart, the height of the light house is
Solution:
In ΔABC
tan 60 = AB/BC
⇒ √3 = AB/BC
AB = √3 BC ----(1)
In ΔABD
tan 45 = AB/BD
⇒ 1 = AB/BD
AB = BD ----(2)
⇒ BD = √3 BC
⇒ BD = BC + CD
⇒ √3 BC = BC + 300
⇒ BC (√3 – 1) = 300
⇒ BC = 300/(√3 – 1) × [(√3 + 1)/(√3 + 1)]
⇒ BC = 300/2 × (√3 + 1)
⇒ BC = 150 (√3 + 1)
From equation (1)
AB = 150 (√3 + 1) × √3
∴ AB = 150 (3 + √3)
